articles.headline: Bad Trades, Except in Korea
articles.snippet: Legal rulings in South Korea are allowing companies to escape, at least temporarily, from disastrously bad trades made with banks in currency contracts.
articles.abstract: Legal rulings in South Korea are allowing companies to escape, at least temporarily, from disastrously bad trades made with banks in currency contracts.
articles.lead_paragraph: The big banks made a lot of bad trades that cost them billions of dollars. Now they may lose money on the good trades they made.

articles.headline: Finding Hope Online, and Hoping a Job Follows
articles.snippet: A laid-off window installer says he has applied unsuccessfully for dozens of jobs in the past year.
articles.abstract: A laid-off window installer says he has applied unsuccessfully for dozens of jobs in the past year.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, S.C. — Nearly a year after he was laid off from his job as a window installer, Raymond Vaughn is still out of work, still scanning job listings on the computer and still sending résumés into a seemingly indifferent void.

articles.headline: Blagojevich Charged With 16 Corruption Felonies
articles.snippet: In a 19-count indictment of the former Illinois governor, prosecutors laid out a vast racketeering scheme.
articles.abstract: In a 19-count indictment of the former Illinois governor, prosecutors laid out a vast racketeering scheme.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO  Rod R. Blagojevich, the ousted governor of Illinois, used his chance to fill the Senate seat vacated by Barack Obama as one more money-making plan in a vast racketeering scheme, federal prosecutors said Thursday, an operation they portrayed as the “Blagojevich Enterprise.”
articles.byline: By Monica Davey and Susan Saulny

articles.headline: U.S. May Let Rivals Share Tanker Deal
articles.snippet: Some leading lawmakers and military analysts are suggesting that splitting a $35 billion contract between Boeing and EADS-Northrop Grumman may be the only way to break an impasse.
articles.abstract: Some leading lawmakers and military analysts are suggesting that splitting a $35 billion contract between Boeing and EADS-Northrop Grumman may be the only way to break an impasse.
articles.lead_paragraph: During the last eight years, the Air Force has twice botched efforts to award one of the Pentagon’s richest contracts, a $35 billion order for tankers that can refuel warplanes in midair.

articles.headline: Banks Face Big Losses From Bets on Chinese Realty
articles.snippet: Foreign investors’ typical strategy — pump capital into a developer, encourage it to buy land, then wait for a big I.P.O. — went badly awry.
articles.abstract: Foreign investors’ typical strategy — pump capital into a developer, encourage it to buy land, then wait for a big I.P.O. — went badly awry.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI  Back in the good old days  early 2007  bankers from Merrill Lynch, Deutsche Bank and other financial giants placed their bets on a 48-year-old property tycoon who was supposed to be China’s next billionaire.

articles.headline: Falling Prices Draw First-Time Home Buyers
articles.snippet: Severe declines in real estate values are helping buyers who were previously priced out: middle-class families with steady jobs.
articles.abstract: Severe declines in real estate values are helping buyers who were previously priced out: middle-class families with steady jobs.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI  While her friends ran up credit card debt and bought show homes beyond their means, Taina Goldman saved for a down payment. She moved back in with her parents, sharing a room with her young daughter, ate in and worked two jobs.

articles.headline: On the World Stage, Obama Issues an Overture
articles.snippet: In his debut summit meeting, President Obama stressed the need for a united front to combat the downturn.
articles.abstract: In his debut summit meeting, President Obama stressed the need for a united front to combat the downturn.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON  In his debut on the international stage, President Obama presented himself as the leader of an America that can no longer go it alone, and as abiding by the protocol of a global new deal.

articles.headline: 663,000 Jobs Lost in March; Total Tops 5 Million
articles.snippet: The U.S. unemployment rate reached 8.5 percent, its highest level in a quarter-century, in a sign of the severity of the downturn.
articles.abstract: The U.S. unemployment rate reached 8.5 percent, its highest level in a quarter-century, in a sign of the severity of the downturn.
articles.lead_paragraph: With 663,000 more jobs disappearing from the American economy last month, swelling the total number of jobs surrendered to the recession beyond five million, the government’s response to the downturn is being put to a strenuous test.
articles.byline: By Peter S. Goodman and Jack Healy

articles.headline: Iowa Court Voids Gay Marriage Ban
articles.snippet: A unanimous ruling has made Iowa the first Midwestern state where same-sex marriage will be legal.
articles.abstract: A unanimous ruling has made Iowa the first Midwestern state where same-sex marriage will be legal.
articles.lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — Same-sex couples will be allowed to marry in Iowa by month’s end, after a ruling on Friday by the Iowa Supreme Court that found unconstitutional a state law limiting marriage to a man and a woman.
